A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

As a Torts Attorney, to solve this problem, we'll analyze the given information and apply the modified comparative negligence statute of the jurisdiction.

1. **Understanding the Statute:** The statute states that a negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided the plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's. Otherwise, no recovery is permitted.

2. **Applying the Statute to the Facts:** The friend (plaintiff) suffered injuries due to the negligence of the fan (the plaintiff's companion) and the driver of the other car (defendant).

3. **Comparative Negligence Findings:** The jury's verdict attributed:
   - 55% negligence to the fan (who is not the defendant in this case),
   - 45% negligence to the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light.

4. **Calculating Damages Based on Negligence:** The friend seeks to recover damages from the driver. According to the statute, the friend's recovery against the driver is not barred since the friend's negligence (imputed from his companion's negligence in this scenario) is not the issue here, but rather the friend's right to recover from the driver based on the driver's negligence. Thus, the friend can recover damages proportionate to the driver's negligence.

5. **Determining the Judgment Amount:** Given the driver's negligence was 45% of the total, and the friend suffered $100,000 in damages, the friend's recovery against the driver would be 45% of $100,000, which equals $45,000.

**Solution:** The correct answer is A) $45,000.00.

The friend will recover $45,000 from the driver, as the driver's negligence contributed 45% to the cause of the accident, thereby entitling the friend to 45% of the total damages incurred.

additional_args.input_str:
A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

additional_args.input_str:
A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

additional_args.input_str:
A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

additional_args.input_str:
A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

additional_args.input_str:
A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

As a Torts Attorney, to solve this problem, we'll analyze the given information and apply the modified comparative negligence statute of the jurisdiction.

1. **Understanding the Statute:** The statute states that a negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided the plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's. Otherwise, no recovery is permitted.

2. **Applying the Statute to the Facts:** The friend (plaintiff) suffered injuries due to the negligence of the fan (the plaintiff's companion) and the driver of the other car (defendant).

3. **Comparative Negligence Findings:** The jury's verdict attributed:
   - 55% negligence to the fan (who is not the defendant in this case),
   - 45% negligence to the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light.

4. **Calculating Damages Based on Negligence:** The friend seeks to recover damages from the driver. According to the statute, the friend's recovery against the driver is not barred since the friend's negligence (imputed from his companion's negligence in this scenario) is not the issue here, but rather the friend's right to recover from the driver based on the driver's negligence. Thus, the friend can recover damages proportionate to the driver's negligence.

5. **Determining the Judgment Amount:** Given the driver's negligence was 45% of the total, and the friend suffered $100,000 in damages, the friend's recovery against the driver would be 45% of $100,000, which equals $45,000.

**Solution:** The correct answer is A) $45,000.00.

The friend will recover $45,000 from the driver, as the driver's negligence contributed 45% to the cause of the accident, thereby entitling the friend to 45% of the total damages incurred.

additional_args.input_str:
A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

additional_args.input_str:
A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

additional_args.input_str:
A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

additional_args.input_str:
A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

additional_args.input_str:
A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

additional_args.input_str:
A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

additional_args.input_str:
A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

additional_args.input_str:
A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

additional_args.input_str:
A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

additional_args.input_str:
A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

additional_args.input_str:
A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

additional_args.input_str:
A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

additional_args.input_str:
A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

additional_args.input_str:
A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

additional_args.input_str:
A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

additional_args.input_str:
A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

additional_args.input_str:
A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

additional_args.input_str:
A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

additional_args.input_str:
A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

additional_args.input_str:
A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

additional_args.input_str:
A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

additional_args.input_str:
A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

additional_args.input_str:
A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

Torts Attorney: As a Torts Attorney, to solve this problem, we'll analyze the given information and apply the modified comparative negligence statute of the jurisdiction.

1. **Understanding the Statute:** The statute states that a negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided the plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's. Otherwise, no recovery is permitted.

2. **Applying the Statute to the Facts:** The friend (plaintiff) suffered injuries due to the negligence of the fan (the plaintiff's companion) and the driver of the other car (defendant).

3. **Comparative Negligence Findings:** The jury's verdict attributed:
   - 55% negligence to the fan (who is not the defendant in this case),
   - 45% negligence to the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light.

4. **Calculating Damages Based on Negligence:** The friend seeks to recover damages from the driver. According to the statute, the friend's recovery against the driver is not barred since the friend's negligence (imputed from his companion's negligence in this scenario) is not the issue here, but rather the friend's right to recover from the driver based on the driver's negligence. Thus, the friend can recover damages proportionate to the driver's negligence.

additional_args.input_str:
A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

additional_args.input_str:
A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. additional_args.input_str:
A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
F) $45,000.00 but only from the driver's insurance
G) $55,000. 00
H) $55,000.00 but only from the fan's insurance
I) $55,000.00 from the driver as the fan was more negligent
J) $100,000. 00

additional_args.task_instruction: Answer the provided question by choosing one option. Include the letter corresponding to your answer in the solution.
additional_args.input_str:
A baseball fan purchased two tickets for a World Series baseball game. The fan contacted his best friend and invited him to go to the game. The friend, who was a fanatic baseball fan, eagerly agreed. The fan told the friend that the game started at 7:00 p. m. and that he would pick him up at about 5:00 p. m. so they could get there early to watch batting practice. They were driving to the game together when the fan sped up to cross an intersection while the traffic signal was changing from amber to red. As he reached the intersection, the fan was traveling at 50 m. p. h. although the posted speed limit was 25 m. p. h. Simultaneously, a car entered the intersection on red and collided with the fan's vehicle. The friend suffered a broken pelvis in the collision. This jurisdiction has adopted the following modified comparative negligence statute:A negligent plaintiff is entitled to obtain a recovery provided plaintiff's negligence is not equal to or greater than that of the defendant's; otherwise no recovery is permitted. Suppose the friend brings suit against the driver of the car that entered the intersection on the red light to recover damages for his injury. Ajury returned a special verdict with the following findings: (1) The fan was 55 percent negligent in speeding; (2) The driver was 45 percent negligent in driving through the red light; and (3) The friend suffered $100,000 in damages. As a result, the court should enter a judgment for the friend in the amount of

A) $45,000. 00
B) $50,000.00
C) nothing, because the fan was more negligentthan the driver.
D) A split judgment where the fan pays $55,000.00 and the driver pays $45,000.00
E) $100,000.00 but paid by both the fan and the driver
